fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities.
  273lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha  : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to  A) \to  A, satisfying:
       \begin {align*}       \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . a) &= a\\       \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ  \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda  p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))      \end {align*}   
  275lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \oplus _s with arity n \cong  P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations:
       \begin {align*}       \oplus _\iota \ (\oplus _s\ \vec {t}) &= \oplus _s\ \vec {t}\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _\iota \ t_1)\ \dots \ (\oplus _\iota \ t_n) &= \oplus _s\ t_1\ \dots \ t_n\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _{f(1)}\ \vec {t_1})\ \dots \ (\oplus _{f(n)}\ \vec {t_n}) &= \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)}\ \vec {t_1}\ \dots \ \vec {t_n}     \end {align*}   
  I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \oplus _\iota  is not necessarily unary in that case, and \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)} may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \oplus _{f(i)} - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomial functors and polynomial monads
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{ Gambino_Kock_2013, title={Polynomial functors and polynomial monads}, volume={154}, ISSN={0305-0041, 1469-8064}, DOI={10.1017/S0305004112000394}, note={arXiv:0906.4931 [math]}, number={1}, journal={Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society}, author={Gambino, Nicola and Kock, Joachim}, year={2013}, month=jan, pages={153â€“192} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I was previously using Obsidian for my research diary, but I found it a little heavyweight for what I was using it for: weekly (or fortnightly) notes on what I've been thinking about.

Being able to "transclude" trees into other ones is another reason why I'm using Forester for this. Writing definitions once and then including them as many times as needed seems far better than having to jump inbetween files.

Most recent entry:
287dia-0003dia-0003.xmlDiary: Monad container algebras2024129Chris Purdy
Previous entry, Next entry
This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.
By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities. 273lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to A) \to A, satisfying: \begin {align*} \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a) &= a\\ \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p)) \end {align*} 275lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \oplus _s with arity n \cong P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations: \begin {align*} \oplus _\iota \ (\oplus _s\ \vec {t}) &= \oplus _s\ \vec {t}\\ \oplus _s\ (\oplus _\iota \ t_1)\ \dots \ (\oplus _\iota \ t_n) &= \oplus _s\ t_1\ \dots \ t_n\\ \oplus _s\ (\oplus _{f(1)}\ \vec {t_1})\ \dots \ (\oplus _{f(n)}\ \vec {t_n}) &= \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)}\ \vec {t_1}\ \dots \ \vec {t_n} \end {align*} I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \oplus _\iota is not necessarily unary in that case, and \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)} may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \oplus _{f(i)} - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.
An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

Earlier this week Stef and I were working on the monad container distributive law project. We had a very insightful meeting with Dan Marsden who mentioned (among other things) that we should look for applications for our characterisation. Things to try:
Find characterisations for tighter classes of monad containers (i.e. commutative, affine, relevant) and see if this simplifies the distributive law. We have already characterised distributive laws for cartesian monad containers for example.
Prove more than just mere existence of distributive laws - use the characterisation to find exactly how many there are for a given pair of monad containers.
Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
Find which algebraic theories correspond to container monads, to tie our work to Maaike Zwart and Dan's work on distributive laws for algebraic theories.

A container S \triangleright P is finitary when its extension functor is finitary (preserves filtered colimits). A monad container is finitary when the underlying container is. 267#245unstable-245.xmlProposition2024129Chris Purdy
A container is finitary if and only if for all s : S, the set P\ s is isomorphic to some finite cardinal. TODO: reference Kock here

Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
